column2: When Paul Morgan, a rising young lawyer with justifiable political aspirations, married Elinor Ashton, leading woman at the Green Square Theatre, his old schoolmates and neighbours back in Spring Valley held up their hands in horror, and his father and mother up in the weather-grey Morgan homestead were crushed in the depths of humiliation.
column3: When Paul Morgan, a rising young lawyer with justifiable political aspirations, married Elinor Ashton, leading woman at the Green Square Theatre, his old schoolmates and neighbours back in Spring Valley held up their hands in horror, and his father and mother up in the weather grey Morgan homestead were crushed in the depths of humiliation.

column2: They had been too proud of Paul ... their only son and such a clever fellow ... and this was their punishment!
column3: They had been too proud of Paul ... their only son and such a clever fellow ... and this was their punishment!

column2: He had married an actress!
column3: He had married an actress!

column2: To Cyrus and Deborah Morgan, brought up and nourished all their lives on the strictest and straightest of old-fashioned beliefs both as regards this world and that which is to come, this was a tragedy.
column3: To Cyrus and Deborah Morgan, brought up and nourished all their lives on the strictest and straightest of old-fashioned beliefs both as regards this world and that which is to come, this was a tragedy.

column2: They could not be brought to see it in any other light.
column3: They could not be brought to see it in any other light.

column2: As their neighbours said, "Cy Morgan never hilt up his head again after Paul married the play-acting woman." But perhaps it was less his humiliation than his sorrow which bowed down his erect form and sprinkled grey in his thick black hair that fifty years had hitherto spared.
column3: As their neighbours said, "Cy Morgan never hilt up his head again after Paul married the play acting woman." But perhaps it was less his humiliation than his sorrow which bowed down his erect form and sprinkled grey in his thick black hair that fifty years had hitherto spared.

column2: For Paul, forgetting the sacrifices his mother and father had made for him, had bitterly resented the letter of protest his father had written concerning his marriage.
column3: For Paul, forgetting the sacrifices his mother and father had made for him, had bitterly resented the letter of protest his father had written concerning his marriage.

column2: He wrote one angry, unfilial letter back and then came silence.
column3: He wrote one angry, unfilial letter back and then came silence.

column2: Between grief and shame Cyrus and Deborah Morgan grew old rapidly in the year that followed.
column3: Between grief and shame Cyrus and Deborah Morgan grew old rapidly in the year that followed.

column2: At the end of that time Elinor Morgan, the mother of an hour, died; three months later Paul Morgan was killed in a railroad collision. After the funeral Cyrus Morgan brought home to his wife their son's little daughter, Joscelyn Morgan.
column3: At the end of that time Elinor Morgan, the mother of an hour, died; three months later Paul Morgan was killed in a railroad collision. After the funeral Cyrus Morgan brought home to his wife their son's little daughter, Joscelyn Morgan.

column2: Cyrus Morgan had been almost rude in his refusal.
column3: Cyrus Morgan had been almost rude in his refusal.

column2: His son's daughter should never be brought up by an actress; it was bad enough that her mother had been one and had doubtless transmitted the taint to her child.
column3: His son's daughter should never be brought up by an actress; it was bad enough that her mother had been one and had doubtless transmitted the taint to her child.

column2: But in Spring Valley, if anywhere, it might be eradicated.
column3: But in Spring Valley, if anywhere, it might be eradicated.

column2: At first neither Cyrus nor Deborah cared much for Joscelyn.
column3: At first neither Cyrus nor Deborah cared much for Joscelyn.

column2: They resented her parentage, her strange, un-Morgan-like name, and the pronounced resemblance she bore to the dark-haired, dark-eyed mother they had never seen.

column2: All the Morgans had been fair.
column3: All the Morgans had been fair.

column3: If Joscelyn had had Paul's blue eyes and golden curls her grandfather and grandmother would have loved her sooner.

column3: But the love came ... it had to.

column2: No living mortal could have resisted Joscelyn.
column3: No living mortal could have resisted Joscelyn.

column2: She was the most winsome and lovable little mite of babyhood that ever toddled.
column3: She was the most winsome and lovable little mite of babyhood that ever toddled.

column3: Her big dark eyes overflowed with laughter before she could speak, her puckered red mouth broke constantly into dimples and cooing sounds.

column2: She had ways that no orthodox Spring Valley baby ever thought of having.
column3: She had ways that no orthodox Spring Valley baby ever thought of having.

column2: Every smile was a caress, every gurgle of attempted speech a song.
column3: Every smile was a caress, every gurgle of attempted speech a song.

column3: Her grandparents came to worship her and were stricter than ever with her by reason of their love.

column2: Because she was so dear to them she must be saved from her mother's blood.
column3: Because she was so dear to them she must be saved from her mother's blood.

column3: Joscelyn shot up through a roly poly childhood into slim, bewitching girlhood in a chill repressive atmosphere.

column2: Cyrus and Deborah were nothing if not thorough.
column3: Cyrus and Deborah were nothing if not thorough.

column2: The name of Joscelyn's mother was never mentioned to her; she was never called anything but Josie, which sounded more "Christian-like" than Joscelyn; and all the flowering out of her alien beauty was repressed as far as might be in the plainest and dullest of dresses and the primmest arrangement possible to riotous ripe-brown curls.
column3: The name of Joscelyn's mother was never mentioned to her; she was never called anything but Josie, which sounded more "Christian like" than Joscelyn; and all the flowering out of her alien beauty was repressed as far as might be in the plainest and dullest of dresses and the primmest arrangement possible to riotous ripe brown curls.

column3: The girl was never allowed to visit her Aunt Annice, although frequently invited.

column3: The path thus set for Joscelyn's dancing feet to walk in was indeed sedate and narrow.

column2: She was seldom allowed to mingle with the young people of even quiet, harmless Spring Valley; she was never allowed to attend local concerts, much less take part in them; she was forbidden to read novels, and Cyrus Morgan burned an old copy of Shakespeare which Paul had given him years ago and which he had himself read and treasured, lest its perusal should awaken unlawful instincts in Joscelyn's heart.
column3: She was seldom allowed to mingle with the young people of even quiet, harmless Spring Valley; she was never allowed to attend local concerts, much less take part in them; she was forbidden to read novels, and Cyrus Morgan burned an old copy of Shakespeare which Paul had given him years ago and which he had himself read and treasured, lest its perusal should awaken unlawful instincts in Joscelyn's heart.

column2: She was sweet-tempered and sunny, truthful and modest, but she was as little like the trim, simple Spring Valley girls as a crimson rose is like a field daisy, and her unlikeness bore heavily on her grandparents.
column3: She was sweet tempered and sunny, truthful and modest, but she was as little like the trim, simple Spring Valley girls as a crimson rose is like a field daisy, and her unlikeness bore heavily on her grandparents.

column2: Our girl Josie, as they called her, was more to them than they would have admitted even to themselves, and in the main they were satisfied with her, although the grandmother grumbled because Josie did not take kindly to patchwork and rug-making and the grandfather would fain have toned down that exuberance of beauty and vivacity into the meeker pattern of maidenhood he had been accustomed to.

column2: When Joscelyn was seventeen Deborah Morgan noticed a change in her. The girl became quieter and more brooding, falling at times into strange, idle reveries, with her hands clasped over her knee and her big eyes fixed unseeingly on space; or she would creep away for solitary rambles in the beech wood, going away droopingly and returning with dusky glowing cheeks and a nameless radiance, as of some newly discovered power, shining through every muscle and motion. Mrs. Morgan thought the child needed a tonic and gave her sulphur and molasses.

column2: When Cyrus Morgan returned home on the evening after his granddaughter's departure he told his wife that she was never to mention the girl's name in his hearing again.
column3: When Cyrus Morgan returned home on the evening after his granddaughter's departure he told his wife that she was never to mention the girl's name in his hearing again.

column2: Deborah obeyed.
column3: Deborah obeyed.

column2: She thought her husband was right, albeit she might in her own heart deplore the necessity of such a decree.

column2: Joscelyn had disgraced them; could that be forgiven?
column3: Joscelyn had disgraced them; could that be forgiven?

column2: Nevertheless both the old people missed her terribly.
column3: Nevertheless both the old people missed her terribly.

column2: The house seemed to have lost its soul with that vivid, ripely tinted young life.
column3: The house seemed to have lost its soul with that vivid, ripely tinted young life.

column2: They got their married daughter's oldest girl, Pauline, to come and stay with them.
column3: They got their married daughter's oldest girl, Pauline, to come and stay with them.

column2: Pauline was a quiet, docile maiden, industrious and commonplace--just such a girl as they had vainly striven to make of Joscelyn, to whom Pauline had always been held up as a model.
column3: Pauline was a quiet, docile maiden, industrious and commonplace-just such a girl as they had vainly striven to make of Joscelyn, to whom Pauline had always been held up as a model.

column2: Yet neither Cyrus nor Deborah took to her, and they let her go unregretfully when they found that she wished to return home.
column3: Yet neither Cyrus nor Deborah took to her, and they let her go unregretfully when they found that she wished to return home.

column2: She hasn't any of Josie's gimp, was old Cyrus's unspoken fault. Deborah spoke, but all she said was, "Polly's a good girl, Father, only she hasn't any snap."
column3: She hasn't any of Josie's gimp, was old Cyrus's unspoken fault. Deborah spoke, but all she said was, "Polly's a good girl, Father, only she hasn't any snap."

column2: Joscelyn wrote to Deborah occasionally, telling her freely of her plans and doings.
column3: Joscelyn wrote to Deborah occasionally, telling her freely of her plans and doings.

column2: If it hurt the girl that no notice was ever taken of her letters she still wrote them.
column3: If it hurt the girl that no notice was ever taken of her letters she still wrote them.

column2: Deborah read the letters grimly and then left them in Cyrus's way.
column3: Deborah read the letters grimly and then left them in Cyrus's way.

column2: Cyrus would not read them at first; later on he read them stealthily when Deborah was out of the house.
column3: Cyrus would not read them at first; later on he read them stealthily when Deborah was out of the house.

column2: When Joscelyn began to succeed she sent to the old farmhouse papers and magazines containing her photographs and criticisms of her plays and acting.
column3: When Joscelyn began to succeed she sent to the old farmhouse papers and magazines containing her photographs and criticisms of her plays and acting.

column2: Deborah cut them out and kept them in her upper bureau drawer with Joscelyn's letters.
column3: Deborah cut them out and kept them in her upper bureau drawer with Joscelyn's letters.

column2: A month later Deborah discovered it between the leaves of the family Bible.
column3: A month later Deborah discovered it between the leaves of the family Bible.

column2: But Joscelyn's name was never mentioned between them, and when other people asked them concerning her their replies were cold and ungracious.
column3: But Joscelyn's name was never mentioned between them, and when other people asked them concerning her their replies were cold and ungracious.

column2: In a way they had relented towards her, but their shame of her remained.
column3: In a way they had relented towards her, but their shame of her remained.

column2: They could never forget that she was an actress.
column3: They could never forget that she was an actress.

column2: Once, six years after Joscelyn had left Spring Valley, Cyrus, who was reading a paper by the table, got up with an angry exclamation and stuffed it into the stove, thumping the lid on over it with grim malignity.
column3: Once, six years after Joscelyn had left Spring Valley, Cyrus, who was reading a paper by the table, got up with an angry exclamation and stuffed it into the stove, thumping the lid on over it with grim malignity.

column2: That fool dunno what he's talking about, was all he would say. Deborah had her share of curiosity.

column2: The paper was the _National Gazette_ and she knew that their next-door neighbour, James Pennan, took it.

column2: She went over that evening and borrowed it, saying that their own had been burned before she had had time to read the serial in it. With one exception she read all its columns carefully without finding anything to explain her husband's anger.
column3: She went over that evening and borrowed it, saying that their own had been burned before she had had time to read the serial in it. With one exception she read all its columns carefully without finding anything to explain her husband's anger.

column2: And we're getting kind of mossy, I guess, never stirring out of Spring Valley.
column3: And we're getting kind of mossy, I guess, never stirring out of Spring Valley.

column2: Let's go and dissipate for a week--what say?"
column3: Let's go and dissipate for a week-what say?"

column2: Deborah agreed readily, albeit of late years she had been much averse to going far from home and had never at any time been very fond of Cousin Hiram's wife.
column3: Deborah agreed readily, albeit of late years she had been much averse to going far from home and had never at any time been very fond of Cousin Hiram's wife.

column2: Cyrus was as pleased as a child over their trip. On the second day of their sojourn in the city he slipped away when Deborah had gone shopping with Mrs. Hiram and hurried through the streets to the Green Square Theatre with a hang-dog look.
column3: Cyrus was as pleased as a child over their trip. On the second day of their sojourn in the city he slipped away when Deborah had gone shopping with mrs Hiram and hurried through the streets to the Green Square Theatre with a hang dog look.

column2: He bought a ticket apologetically and sneaked in to his seat.
column3: He bought a ticket apologetically and sneaked in to his seat.

column2: It was a matinee performance, and Joscelyn Morgan was starring in her famous new play.
column3: It was a matinee performance, and Joscelyn Morgan was starring in her famous new play.

column2: Cyrus waited for the curtain to rise, feeling as if every one of his Spring Valley neighbours must know where he was and revile him for it. If Deborah were ever to find out ... but Deborah must never find out! For the first time in their married life the old man deliberately plotted to deceive his old wife.
column3: Cyrus waited for the curtain to rise, feeling as if every one of his Spring Valley neighbours must know where he was and revile him for it. column2: He must see his girl Josie just once; it was a terrible thing that she was an actress, but she was a successful one, nobody could deny that, except fools who yapped in the _National Gazette_.
column3: He must see his girl Josie just once; it was a terrible thing that she was an actress, but she was a successful one, nobody could deny that, except fools who yapped in the underscore National Gazette underscore.

column2: The curtain went up and Cyrus rubbed his eyes.
column3: The curtain went up and Cyrus rubbed his eyes.

column2: He had certainly braced his nerves to behold some mystery of iniquity; instead he saw an old kitchen so like his own at home that it bewildered him; and there, sitting by the cheery wood stove, in homespun gown, with primly braided hair, was Joscelyn--his girl Josie, as he had seen her a thousand times by his own ingle-side.
column3: He had certainly braced his nerves to behold some mystery of iniquity; instead he saw an old kitchen so like his own at home that it bewildered him; and there, sitting by the cheery wood stove, in homespun gown, with primly braided hair, was Joscelyn-his girl Josie, as he had seen her a thousand times by his own ingle side.

column2: The building rang with applause; one old man pulled out a red bandanna and wiped tears of joy and pride from his eyes.
column3: The building rang with applause; one old man pulled out a red bandanna and wiped tears of joy and pride from his eyes.

column2: She hadn't changed--Josie hadn't changed.

column2: Play-acting hadn't spoiled her--couldn't spoil her.

column2: Wasn't she Paul's daughter! And all this applause was for her--for Josie.
column3: Wasn't she Paul's daughter! And all this applause was for her-for Josie.

column3: Joscelyn's new play was a homely, pleasant production with rollicking comedy and heart moving pathos skilfully commingled.

column2: Joscelyn pervaded it all with a convincing simplicity that was really the triumph of art.
column3: Joscelyn pervaded it all with a convincing simplicity that was really the triumph of art.
